body.p:
I write to you
in the shape of a note be
cause I am anxious to forward
you two poems by the same
post and for the same postage
and as I have but little in
teresting to communicate the
apparent brevity of my epistle
you will I trust kindly excuse

I owe you an apology
for not having answered your
kind favor of 10 January long
ere this, but continued indis
position since the early part
of March and a very long
task of writing which I had
to finish as speedily as possible
prevented my addressing any
of my correspondents and ?

p.rend: The following (page 5) is written in the opposite direction over the above text.

body.p:
where you have any money in hand for
me. Do not procure them till? you can pay yourself
from any money you may have to transmit
to me & then I should be obliged by your
forwarding them by the first opportunity I think
my name had better be written in them or they
will not pass without a fine which I have no in
clination to pay. Papa begged me to inform
you he had a small parcel for you from the Miss
? which he will forward by the first opportunity

Trusting this letter will find you in
health & prosperity ? in all your undertakings

I trust plead my excuse with
you as with others. Allow me
to thank you for the 1st number
of your periodical, which my
brother brought me from Mr Franklin
without however any message, so
I do not know whether you sent
any with it and also let me
thank you, for the very grati
fying notice with which you
introduce my little poem “The
Chambers of the Dying” to your
readers, in your second number.
I trust the poems I send may
prove suitable and acceptable
the intent of both is to bring
us closer to the gracious Saviours
of Israel, than is often unhappily
the case with our nation. They
generally place Him at a
distance. I never think of deriving
comfort from the fact that He
knows & loves us better than
our dearest Friends on Earth, & feels

and shares every pang His Love
inflicts. The Hour of peace is
simply to rob Death of its gloom
Oh that Immortality were more
thought of amongst us, than it is!

I regret not yet having had
time to read your periodical
with sufficient attention to pass
an opinion upon it. You have
however my very best wishes
for its success, as its design is
praiseworthy and the labour
to yourself must I think be very
great. My Father begs I
will deliver you his kind regards
and our united thanks for the
detailed account of the books, which
your last favor contained. I trust
ere this, you have received
some returns from the different
places to which they have been
sent. In Jamaica & St Thomas
I know they have had some
sale, as the fact has travelled

to us in England. I do not
much understand business my
self, but so that the slowness of
payment appears to me rather
strange. You are right in sup
posing gain was not my object
in publishing the work, but yet
I am not rich or even independent
enough, not to feel anxious to
receive that, which if the books
are sold or even some of them have are
sold at the places to which they
have been sent, must be my
due an anxiety which I have
no doubt you can understand
but I know it is not in your
power to remidy it. You will
oblige me greatly however by
urging your agents to a settlement
for those they have sold. With
regard to Dr Channings? works
which you say can be procured
in 5 vols for 4 Dollars—I
should like much to have them
